node.title: Signs of Sea Change at Art Basel Miami: More Galleries of Color
node.alt: The Tanzanian artist Sungi Mlengeya, right, at the Afriart Gallery space at Art Basel Miami Beach with her portrait paintings of women.
node.description: Changes to eligibility requirements enabled more diversity at the fair, which roared back for the first time since the pandemic.
node.content: ["MIAMI BEACH, Fla. \u2014 Kendra Jayne Patrick\u2019s booth was buzzing at Art Basel on Tuesday during the V.I.P. opening as visitors crowded in to admire \u2014 and consider buying \u2014 pieces by the tapestry artist Qualeasha Wood, whose work is currently on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.", "In the past, Patrick would not have been eligible to participate in the fair, because her New York gallery has no permanent physical space. But over the past year, Art Basel changed its admission requirements and made a concerted effort to invite previously marginalized galleries to apply.", " \u201cWe wanted to lower the obstacles to entry \u2014 not around quality, but around how long you had to be in business and what the nature of your business is,\u201d said Marc Spiegler, Art Basel\u2019s global director. \u201cThese galleries have enough hurdles without our having these regulations, which are outdated.\u201d", "The shift was noteworthy, given that Art Basel\u2019s online iteration in June 2020 did not include a single African-American-owned gallery. The 253 galleries in the Miami Beach Convention Center this year featured several first-time participants of color, including four galleries owned by Black Americans, three from Africa, eight from Latin America and one from Korea.", "This increasing diversity was just one way the pandemic altered the Art Basel Miami Beach fair\u2019s first in-person gathering since 2019. There were also required health screenings, timed entry of visitors and mandatory masks (with loudspeaker reminders to keep them on). And some galleries reported not receiving art pieces (and booth furniture) in time because of supply-chain problems.", "The four galleries from South Africa made it to the fair just under the wire, given the emergence of the Omicron variant and President Biden\u2019s decision to restrict travel from the country starting Nov. 29. Rather than feel ostracized, these galleries said visitors went out of their way to welcome them at the fair \u2014 a few keep-your-distance jokes notwithstanding.", "Discussion of NFTs \u2014 nonfungible tokens \u2014 was also coursing through the balmy air, though they have been slow to catch on with veteran collectors. Pace Gallery made its first NFT art fair sale \u2014 a collaboration between Studio Drift in Amsterdam and the musician Don Diablo for $500,000 (plus $50,000 donated to climate protection efforts).", "Overall, however, the fair \u2014 as well as its myriad satellite events, such as Untitled, NADA and Design Miami \u2014 provided further proof that the art market is largely immune to social and political upheaval. ", "Most galleries, particularly blue-chip dealers, reported strong sales, including a Noah Davis painting that went for $1.4 million and an Ad Reinhardt abstract for more than $7 million at David Zwirner, as well as a Keith Haring for $1.75 million and an Elizabeth Murray for $725,000 at Gladstone. Salon 94 sold a double Dutch jump rope sculpture by Karon Davis for $150,000 to the streetwear mogul James Whitner.", "\u201cIt felt a little like Groundhog Day,\u201d said Tim Blum of Blum & Poe gallery. \u201cIf you go through the fair, you might think this is 2019.\u201d", "Indeed, the evenings were full of dinners and parties \u2014 Alicia Keys performed at the immersive exhibition space Superblue in the Miami Design District \u2014 with most decked-out guests not wearing masks (and bemoaning the traffic congestion). Many noted how happy they were to be physically gathering in Miami Beach to view art and embrace each other again (yes, air kissing is back).", "\u201cThere is nothing like seeing people in person and having engaged conversations,\u201d said Jo Stella-Sawicka, the senior director of the Goodman Gallery, which has locations in Johannesburg, Cape Town and London, adding that she was already flying to Florida when news of the new variant broke.", "While the fair\u2019s timed entry precluded the usual opening bell stampede through the doors \u2014 and some collectors groused that they didn\u2019t get the time slots they wanted \u2014 gallerists said the more spaced-out admissions allowed for calmer, more substantive conversations with visitors.", "Though much of the art \u2014 per usual \u2014 had sold in advance through online previews or emailed PDFs, many dealers said several pieces were purchased at the fair itself. ", "Art fairs have long been considered ripe for a correction or consolidation, due to their proliferation and expense. The new firm LGDR \u2014 four powerful dealers who joined forces \u2014 has said it plans to swear off such events in the U.S. ", "But several first-time gallerists said Art Basel offered crucial exposure (they included Rele Gallery from Lagos, which recently opened an L.A. branch, and Nicola Vassell, which just opened in Manhattan\u2019s Chelsea).", "\u201cMiami Basel is so international,\u201d Patrick, the New York dealer, said, \u201cyou can meet a great cross section of clients.\u201d", "Joost Bosland of the South Africa gallery Stevenson had planned to come only briefly to Art Basel, before Omicron changed all that.", "\u201cI was meant to be here for a day,\u201d he said. \u201cThen the rest of the team didn\u2019t make it.\u201d", "SMAC Gallery, which has locations in Cape Town and Johannesburg, barely made it to Miami. \u201cWe had to, or the booth would have been empty,\u201d said Baylon Sandri, one of the directors, adding that the ban was \u201cunfair\u201d because South Africa had only identified the presence of the new variant. ", "Bonolo Kavula, the artist shown by SMAC who was in the booth, said, \u201cNot coming wasn\u2019t an option \u2014 Art Basel is one hell of an opportunity. ", "\u201cI\u2019m not just here for myself,\u201d she added. \u201cIt shows other artists back home that this is possible.\u201d", "KJ Freeman, the owner of Housing gallery on Manhattan\u2019s Lower East Side, was another newcomer benefiting from the expanded participation of smaller galleries. She planned to show the artist Arlene Wandera, whose sculptural pieces never arrived. So Freeman pivoted to presenting Nathaniel Oliver. When all of Oliver\u2019s work sold, she taped a QR code to the wall of her booth through which visitors could view Wandera\u2019s work. ", "\u201cI used to be a performance artist,\u201d Freeman said. \u201cSo I can pretty much make an installation any day of the week.\u201d", "While Freeman said she was happy to have been invited to apply to the fair, she also said her modest operation did not necessarily fit in among the behemoths.", "\u201cI\u2019ve never sold anything beyond five figures \u2014 low five figures,\u201d she said, adding that Wandera\u2019s work was priced at $5,000 to $22,000 and Oliver\u2019s at $3,000 to $18,000. ", "Among the dealers Art Basel invited to apply was Daudi Karungi of Afriart Gallery in Uganda, who said he appreciated the outreach. \u201cIt\u2019s better than me knocking on that door,\u201d he said. ", "Karungi\u2019s booth, featuring a solo presentation of work by the Tanzanian artist Sungi Mlengeya, quickly sold out, with each piece priced between $50,000 and $75,000.", "Ivy N. Jones of the Welancora gallery, which is based in a brownstone in Bedford Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, said it was \u201can honor\u201d to bring the work of Helen Evans Ramsaran, an American sculptor in her 70s. \u201cThere are so many older artists who need somebody to believe in them,\u201d Jones said.", "Similarly, Marcus Gora, co-founder of the First Floor Gallery in Zimbabwe, said the fair gave important visibility for an artist like the one he showed in Miami, Troy Makaza, who combines painting and sculpture. \u201cWe\u2019ve been growing and building,\u201d Gora said. \u201cThis is our gateway into the North American market.\u201d", "Karungi of Afriart said that participating in the fair nearly 20 years after creating his gallery feels like an important milestone and that he hopes to serve as a model for other African galleries. \u201cI started from the bottom in the industry,\u201d he said. \u201cAnd now we\u2019re here.\u201d", ""]
